Algorithm Selection

Decision tree BP Network
Decision Tree is a decision analysis method which is based on the known probability of occurrence of various situations and constructs the decision tree to obtain the probability that the expected value of net present value is greater than or equal to zero, evaluate the project risk, and judge its feasibility. It is a graphical method of intuitive use of probability analysis. A decision tree is a tree-like structure in which each internal node represents a test on an attribute, each branch represents a test output, and each leaf node represents a category. Classification tree (decision tree) is a very common classification method. It is a kind of supervised learning, the so-called supervised learning is given a bunch of samples, each sample has a set of attributes and a category, these categories are determined in advance, then through learning to get a classifier, this classifier can give the correct classification of the newly emerged objects. This kind of machine learning is called supervised learning
The basic BP algorithm includes two processes of signal forward propagation and error back propagation. That is, the error output is calculated in the direction from input to output, while the weight and threshold are adjusted in the direction from output to input. In forward propagation, the input signal acts on the output node through the hidden layer and generates the output signal after nonlinear transformation. If the actual output is inconsistent with the expected output, the error will be transferred to the back propagation process. Error backpropagation is the backpropagation of the output error layer by layer from the hidden layer to the input layer, and the error is allocated to all the elements of each layer, and the error signal obtained from each layer is used as the basis for adjusting the weight of each element. By adjusting the connection strength between the input node and the hidden layer node and the connection strength between the hidden layer node and the output node as well as the threshold, the error decreases along the gradient direction. After repeated learning and training, the network parameters corresponding to the minimum error (weight and threshold) are determined, and the training stops. In this case, the trained neural network can process the non-linear transformed information with minimal output error for the input information of similar samples.

Model Evaluation

Model Evaluation

Model Interpretation

Single Sample 1

The waterfall diagram represents the contribution of all features in the first sample to this sample, with positive contributions in red and negative contributions in blue. The ordinate is the feature name, the abscissa is the contribution value, E[f(x)] represents the average predicted value, and f(x) represents the predicted value of the sample The higher the predicted value, the more likely it is to default.

Single Sample 2

Visual positive and negative

Overall 1: The influence of global features on the predicted value of the model

Rank the importance of features. The abscissa represents the influence on the predicted value of the model, the ordinate represents the name of the feature, the red represents the larger feature value, and the blue represents the smaller feature value For example, it can be seen from the figure above that the larger the v940 feature, the greater the positive contribution to the model output and the greater the default probability.

Overall 2

The importance of each feature to the predicted value.
